page.name: Growth Mindset Helps Learners Build Literacy Skills
page.content:
Whether learners have significant learning differences that they know about or not, the mindset they bring into the classroom about reading will impact their ability to persist (Candy, 2019). Start by teaching them the difference between a growth mindset and a fixed mindset. 

  • Mindset refers to a relation between studentsâ€™ motivation and their learning goals, and their beliefs about whether intelligence and academic skills are fixed (inherent) or can be grown (malleable or incremental).

Learners with a fixed mindset believe their academic ability is already set. They believe that if they can't learn something easily, it's because they aren't smart (Dweck, 2015). 

Learners with a growth mindset believe that intelligence ability can be changed and developed through practice. They embrace feedback because it can help them improve. To individuals with a growth mindset, success is a result of grit, perseverance, effort, and practice (Sahagun et al., 2021).
